results.title: Cornet at night
results.creator_credit: Stanley Jackson, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Tells a haunting story of boyhood on a prairie homestead. The boy, sent to town to find a strong hired hand, returns with a cornet player creating a tense atmosphere at supper. Later while milking, the farmer listens to the cornet, and understands that the boy’s need for music is as great as his own need for adequate help in the fields. The cornet player does not stay, but the echo of his music continues through the years. Based on a story by Sinclair Ross. (Awards: New York)

results.title: Corduroy
results.creator_credit: Gary Templeton, Joe Mantegna, Weston Woods Studios and Evergreen/Firehouse Productions
results.brief_description: The film follows the adventures of a stuffed teddy bear called Corduroy who waits to be selected from the shelves of a department store. To make sure he is not mistaken for used property, he embarks on a quest to find a button that is missing from his overalls. In the process, he discovers a new and deserving owner. Based on the the book by Don Freeman.

results.title: Coral sea dreaming: an evolving balance
results.creator_credit: Ian O'Hare, David Hannan, Natural Symphonies and Coral Sea Imagery
results.brief_description: Coral Sea dreaming is a remarkable visual and musical odyssey into the world of coral reefs. The haunting and magical experiences of the reef realm are communicated through the camera work of David Hannan who teamed with scientist Russell Kelly and artist Cathy Bone to present their “dreaming”. The video is without words, but with a specially composed musical score by Adelaide composer Tania Rose. Scientific understanding begins in seeing. “Coral Sea dreaming” lets you see for yourself, lets you be the explorer. Accompanied by an educational and resource guide.

results.title: Cordelia
results.creator_credit: Jean Beaudin, Jean-Marc Garand and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Guilty of loving life! A dramatisation of an actual court case in turn-of-the-century Quebec. A lively, outgoing woman is accused of murdering her husband in collaboration with the hired hand. The townspeople do not appreciate her robust personality and the proceedings in court degenerate to a judgement of her character. Filled with stunning visual imagery, this feature film captures the spirit of the time and place. Particularly useful for those interested in history, law or women’s studies.

results.title: Copyrites
results.creator_credit: Kim Mordaunt, Cathy Eatock, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: This program poses questions about what happens when Aboriginal concepts of ownership meet Western copyright laws in terms of Aboriginal art, its exhibition and distribution both nationally and internationally. Viewed as central to the lives of Aboriginal people, the art works elucidate a connection to the land and the vital importance of Aboriginal community, cultural and historical traditions. When these forms of expression are illegally reproduced and manufactured the consequences for the artists and the community at large loom further than the Western concept of violation of copyright, an issue that this documentary explores in depth.

results.title: Copycat
results.creator_credit: Jon Amiel, Mark Tarlov, Michael Nathanson, Arnon Milchan, John Fiedler, Joseph Caracciolo Jr and Regency Enterprises
results.brief_description: A murderer is on the loose in San Francisco, constantly staying one step ahead of the police. Criminal psychologist and noted author Helen Hudson (Signourney Weaver) notices the killer’s pattern. He is a copycat and is imitating the serial killers in one of Helen’s novels. She reports this to the police and assists Homicide detective Monahan (Holly Hunter) in the investigation, depsite being agoraphobic and unable to leave home. As their investigation gets closer the catching the killer, they realise his real target is Helen and she must fight to stay alive.

results.title: Work around the clock
results.creator_credit: Ivo Burum, Helen Gaynor, Alfred Hospital and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Nurses”.
Nurses “was filmed by four nurses and their friends at the Alfred Hospital in Melbourne to capture the real life drama of nursing from a very different perspective…their own” Nurses are: Kerryn O’Rourke - Oncology. Trish Builic - Psychiatric (to the homeless). Jane Newham - Emergency. Cassie Steward - Theatre. Ep 2: Opens with wonderfully honest scene about the difficulties of getting up in the morning, and the way the twenty-four hour, year round demands of nursing that throw your body and personal life out. Jane, who has been in a relationship for five months talks about the cycle of crankiness that comes whenever she works nights. And the difficulties of getting a partner, used to a nine to five work day, to understand. Trish, who has just been proposed to (lots of drama) says upfront that she chose to specialise in psychiatric because she didn’t think she could work nights relentlessly, and even so she still carries responsibility beyond working hours. Kerryn takes the audience through a night shift and we see that its the little things that get you through, brushing your teeth, coming home to clean bed sheets. And in theatre there are some gory scenes, before Cassie takes us out the back for a cigarette…

results.title: Coppelia
results.creator_credit: Virginia Lumsden, Autralian Ballet Foundation and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: This ballet, directed by George Ogilvie, tells the story of Dr. Coppelius, a toymaker and magician, who attempts to bring to life his beautiful doll, Coppelia. He is fooled by the mischievous Swanhilda who masquerades as Coppelia and saves her lover Franz, from the Doctors’ magic. Features Colin Peasley, Lisa Pavane, Greg Horsman and the Australian Opera and Ballet Orchestra conducted by Noel Smith. Music by Leo Delibes. Choreography by Arthur Saint-Leon. Revised by Marius Petipa and Enrico Cecchetti. Reproduced with additional choreography by Peggy van Praagh.

results.title: Nursing is tough
results.creator_credit: Ivo Burum, Helen Gaynor, Alfred Hospital and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Nurses”.
‘Nurses’ “was filmed by four nurses and their friends at the Alfred Hospital in Melbourne to capture the real life drama of nursing from a very different perspective…their own” Nurses are: Kerryn O’Rourke - Oncology. Trish Builic - Psychiatric (to the homeless). Jane Newham - Emergency. Cassie Steward - Theatre. Ep 1. Introduction to the nurses, their fields of specialisation, views and experiences. Deals with what attracted the women to nursing in the first place and how their experience has differed from initial expectations. Examines the stereotype of nursing as ‘nice girls’ occupation proposing instead that nursing and by extension nurses are tough. Jane talks about emergency as an experience that brings you face to face with the fundamentals of life and death. Cassie speaks about her foray into nursing as something unfortunately rare for a woman brought up in the western suburbs. Kerryn talks about the sense that it was only in her third year as a registered nurse that the ‘big picture’ of what nursing demands hit her. And Trish articulates the mixed feelings involved in working with homeless psychiatric patients, of “having to force people to do something they don’t want to do, but knowing that if you don’t they end up in pain, vulnerable and traumatised”.
